blog_content:
In this write up we will solve Bandit2 level, doing so will give us the password for level3. We already solved level1 to get the password for Level2 (Read OverTheWire: Bandit: Solving Bandit 1 -> Bandit 2).

The prompt for Level2 is -



The prompt tells us that the password is stored in a file named 'spaces in this filename', which is located in the home directory. Let's try SSHing into the server.

Using the command - 'ssh bandit2@bandit.labs.overthewire.org -p 2220' and the password 'CV1DtqXWVFXTvM2F0k09SHz0YwRINYA9'. We are able to gain access to the system.



Using 'pwd' to see the directory we are in.



It looks like we are in the home directory. Let's use 'ls' to see the contents of the home directory.



We can see that there is a file named 'spaces in this filename' in the home directory.

Now, normally if we use 'cat' as such i.e using the command 'cat spaces in this filename'. The 'cat' binary will treat each word as a filename and then will try and open each files, i.e it will try opening individual files named 'spaces', 'in', 'this', 'filename'. Since these individual files do not exist, 'cat' will give an error, just as shown below -



Now in order to incorporate 'spaces' in the file name we will have to modify the command a bit. We will modify it by using '\' just before the spaces. Doing so will tell the bash interpreter to consider this space as part of the filename and not as a separator between different files. Now the modified command will look like - 'cat spaces\ in\ this\ filename'



This will work for any special characters in bash, such as '<', '>' or '|', without using '\' the bash interpreter will treat them as special characters and give a faulty output.

Success!! we were able to open the file and get the password for level3.

Password for Level3 is: UmHadQclWmgdLOKQ3YNgjWxGoRMb5luK
